channel.title: CSIS — Analysis (custom RSS)
channel.description: Auto-generated RSS feed for CSIS Analysis pages.

item.title: States Weekly: October 22, 2025
item.description: This edition of States Weekly covers October 22, 2025.

item.title: When a Trade War Becomes a Food Fight
item.description: The U.S. agricultural sector is caught in the crossfire of the U.S.-China trade war. As Washington and Beijing escalate tariffs and other retaliatory measures, U.S. farmers are scrambling to find new buyers just as Chinese consumers turn to alternative suppliers.

item.title: False Choices: Balancing Democracy and Development in U.S. Africa Policy
item.description: The shift in U.S. foreign policy to prioritize commercial diplomacy over democracy support presents a false dichotomy. As African partners adjust to the U.S. retreat as an advocate for democracy, this approach risks long-term consequences for U.S.-Africa relations.

item.title: When Crime Becomes Terror: Rethinking the FTO Designation
item.description: CSIS Americas Research Associate Rubi Bledsoe analyzes the recent designations of criminal organizations as FTOs by the Trump administration and discusses key similarities and differences between the groups.

item.title: Ryan Berg in the Hoover Institution: Hemispheric Defense Is Back
item.description: Americas Program Director Ryan C. Berg and Joseph Ledford discuss ways in which the United States can craft a hemispheric strategy with global effectiveness.

item.title: Unpacking Ukraine’s Future Cyber and Space Forces
item.description: This piece explores the key questions surrounding Ukraine's proposed Cyber and Space Forces and what they will mean for the future of warfighting.

item.title: Unpacking the U.S.-Australia Critical Minerals Framework Agreement
item.description: The new U.S.–Australia Critical Minerals Framework cements the alliance as a cornerstone of global minerals security, combining over billions of dollars in joint investments with expanded defense cooperation—and reframing minerals as strategic assets, not just commodities.

item.title: What Goes Around Comes Around and Other Cliches
item.description: This week, Bill Reinsch argues that China’s recent export controls are a direct response to U.S. trade measures. Rather than reacting with outrage, he suggests that the United States should avoid hypocrisy and adopt a more consistent strategy to de-escalate the growing trade tensions.
